## Quarto

Quarto enables you to weave together content and executable code into a finished document. To learn more about Quarto see <https://quarto.org>.

## Running Code

When you click the **Render** button a document will be generated that includes both content and the output of embedded code. You can embed code like this:

```{r}
pacman::p_load(plotly, gt, patchwork, ggstatsplot, tidyverse, ggside, readxl, performance, parameters, see, rstatix,patchwork)
```

You can add options to executable code like this

```{r}
exam_data <- read_csv("data/Exam_data.csv")
```

::: {.panel-tabset}
## The plot
```{r}
#| echo: false 
#| fig-width: 4
#| fig-height: 4
qq <- ggplot(exam_data, aes(sample=ENGLISH))+stat_qq()+stat_qq_line()

sw_t <- exam_data %>% 
  shapiro_test(ENGLISH)%>% 
  gt()

tmp <- tempfile(fileext='.png')
gtsave(sw_t,tmp)
table_png <- png::readPNG(tmp,native=TRUE)

qq+table_png
```
## The code chunk
```{r}
#| eval: false
#| fig-width: 4
#| fig-height: 4
ggplot(exam_data, aes(sample=ENGLISH))+stat_qq()+stat_qq_line()

sw_t <- exam_data %>% 
  shapiro_test(ENGLISH)%>% 
  gt()

```
:::

::: callout-note
We can see that the points deviate significantly form the straight diagonal line, this is a clear indication that the set of data is not normally distributed.
:::
